body:
Seems a frequentish question, and some people have some pretty wild ideas, like thinking we copy-paste all the Unicode ops from some website each time we need them.

Was asked just now on r/perl6: https://www.reddit.com/r/perl6/comments/85bn0b/unicode_operators/

And was asked earlier on this thread too: https://www.reddit.com/r/perl6/comments/6v63wv/201734_going_weekly_changes_in_and_around_perl_6/
title: FAQ: "how most people enter Unicode stuff"

title: ?? !! is pointing to the wrong place
Post release 2018.03

body:
Specifically, if you write code like:

--cut here--
method TOP( $/ ) {
    my $v = ~$/ ~~ /foo/;
}
--cut here--

attempting the /foo/ match fails because $/ is a readonly argument resulting in the error below:

--cut here--
Cannot assign to a readonly variable ($/) or a value.
--cut here--

which is entirely correct, but it may not be obvious that $/ is readonly because you're passing the match as an argument. Granted, it's right there a few lines above, but it confused me.

Maybe the error could be changed to:
--cut here--
Cannot assign to the argument $/.
--cut here--

in this case.
title: The Grammar section could use a warning about using regexes inside an Action.

body:
It's not obvious that `<` … `>` is a LTM; the angle brackets may also be mistaken for rule delimiters.

```perl6
say 'food' ~~ /< f fo foo food >/;      # OUTPUT: «｢food｣␤»
say 'food' ~~ / f | fo | foo | food /;  # OUTPUT: «｢food｣␤»
```
title: Document < … > lists on the regex page

body:
It's a special syntax that lets users write stuff like their own versions of stuff like `<before ...>`. (description copied from https://github.com/rakudo/rakudo/issues/1634#issuecomment-374689565)

> […] it is the syntax that lets us parse `<before abc>` and similar. Unlike with `<foo: ...>` and `<foo(...)>`, where the args are parsed by the MAIN language, the `<foo ...>` form parses the rest of the assertion using the regex language, wraps it in a closure, and passes it to foo. Thus it's a general syntax for higher-order regex operators - which is just what before/after are.

I guess maybe somewhere in the "advanced" section or grammars is a good place to put this. Just to separate it from all the common syntax novice users might be reading through.
title: Document `/<foo ...>/` syntax somewhere

body: I'm considering to split up this section into a mandatory and optional section, to make it clearer what a user *needs*, and what they can additionally use to achieve certain goals (such as semantic versioning, in this case).
title: Update META6.json documentation to include "api" field

body:
I saw ["I tried to find the " $ " in the documentation but couldn't find it."](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/49375773/perl-6-curried-function-hangs#comment85753649_49376083).

I think the closest the docs currently come to what that user needed is [The $ Variable](https://docs.perl6.org/language/variables#The_$_Variable). (It looks like that section could do with a mention of how `$` can be used to mark an unused parameter. Same goes for doc for `@` and `%`.)

I tried typing `$` in the search box. It does not have an entry that links to the doc section I just linked.

(There is an entry toward the end of the large menu that says `$ (variable)`. But that turns out to be an entry for `$<named> (variable)`. You can see this if you use the cursor keys to select it from the menu. The entry is both incorrectly displayed in the menu *and* has a link that lands it at the right page but at the top rather than at the right place for the *Named Attributes* section that discusses `$<named>` variables. I searched for tickets matching `$<named>` and found none. Do we need to create a further one or two new issues to cover these `$<named>` problems?)

Finally, I can also imagine folk typing `$` to get help on `$` as a sigil, and that doesn't seem to be available either, beyond the item contextualiser stuff. I'd expect a link to [Sigils](https://docs.perl6.org/language/variables#Sigils) as well as a link to *The $ variable*.
title: Searching for `$` doesn't lead user to doc about it

body:
Since [the grant has started officially](http://news.perlfoundation.org/2018/02/grant-proposal-curating-and-im.html), one of the things I'd like to do is to have a clearer idea of what visitors do, where they come from, and where we lose them; I'd like to add Google Analytics code to the site and have it working for at least a month. In principle, I'd use my own code, but if there's some official Google account I could use, and whose results I can access, that would be fine.
In principle, I would remove it once I finish the grant, but I can leave it there if it helps, or change it to another one. 
Any ideas for/against?
title: Add Google Analytics code to the website

body: None of the `repr` representation specifiers, as in « class Foo is repr('...') { } » seem to be documented. Typing "repr" or "is" into the search box at https://docs.perl6.org/ does not bring up anything relevant.
title: is repr('...') needs documentation
LTA example of using The $ Variable more than once

body:
If you type `$<named>` in the index the pop up shows $ and $ (variable), which actually point to the `$<named>` entries. `<` are suppressed in the index, although the URL it points to is (kinda) correct. 
Seen when dealing with the #1861 issue.
title: $<named> things not showing up in the search index

body:
See https://github.com/rakudo/rakudo/issues/1644

Basically:
```perl6
$ = {say 42;} # Block
$ = {;}       # Block
$ = {…}       # Block
$ = { }       # Hash
```
title: Empty block trap

body:
On https://docs.perl6.org/language/containers#Type_Constraints  the prose says you can rebind to a variable and remove constraint, yet the very example shown in that section shows that you get an error if you try to do that. Also, it says *"Scalar containers have Any contraint"* by default, but that's not true, as scalar variables default to Mu.

~~Also, I'm not sure, but I don't think the "constraint is a property of the container" part is true at all. 'cause `my Int \x` and `my @foo := 1, 2, 3` have type checks, yet there are no containers involved.~~

IRC: https://irclog.perlgeek.de/perl6/2018-03-26#i_15968146
title: "Type Constraints" section on containers page contains incorrect info
Default type is Mu
link to binding operator
tell that and when := throws X::TypeCheck::BindingType

body:
Hopefully completion of issue #136 that I had to put aside for a while.  Python, Ruby, C# and Delphi all allow 'setters' for attributes that overload the assignment operator so other people from other languages may wonder about the feature.  Patch tries to give just enough to satisfy their curiosity.

Forgot to mention [March 24 IRC discussion](https://irclog.perlgeek.de/perl6/2018-03-24#i_15961290) with @timo when posting.
title: Mention attribute mutators by Proxy and refer to mutators.t in roast

body:
My "Programming Perl" 4th ed has a section called "Accessing Overridden Methods" in its chapter on objects.  There is a sentence for "re-dispatch" at the end of [language/classtut/#Overriding_inherited_methods](https://docs.perl6.org/language/classtut#Overriding_inherited_methods) and `callsame` is mentioned for `BUILDALL` in the "Object Orientation" doc.  The [inheritance section in language/objects](https://docs.perl6.org/language/objects#Inheritance) doesn't mention re-dispatch and I think it should and give an example.  Maybe it can refer to the example for `BUILDALL` but that might be seen as a special case.  Neither Perl 6 document now really covers the concepts from "Accessing Overridden Methods" in "Programming Perl".

See also my confused [#perl6](https://irclog.perlgeek.de/perl6/2018-03-28#i_15976203) discussion earlier today.
title: Re-dispatching needs mention and maybe example in language/objects#Inheritance
